p: Drought can affect social and economic wellbeing within a community through changes to water availability that can impact agriculture [ 176]. The Canadian agricultural sector produced crop and livestock products totaling over $41 billion in 2010 [ 197]. Costs associated with a drought can be significant. For example, total costs of drought across the Prairies in 1990 exceeded $800 million (equivalent 2011 Canadian dollars) [ 198]. The more recent drought of 2001â€“2002 was responsible for $3.6 billion in direct losses related to agricultural production [ 199]. Impacts on agriculture are passed on to the broader community and may lead to temporary unemployment [ 200] and increase stress levels [ 176, 201]. The U.S. drought in the 1930s and its impact on agriculture contributed to the Great Depression; there was high unemployment, increased demands on government aid programs and community impacts as millions of people affected by the drought moved to other communities [ 202].
